conclusion: Trying to figure out the problem of liquid flow from points A, B, and C into containers D or E.
Visualizing the setup with liquid flowing from points A, B, and C through baffles to containers D and E.
Understanding the setup with channels or pipes discharging liquid from A, B, and C, and baffles guiding the flow.
Considering fluid flow paths based on direction and pressure, and baffles guiding flow to D or E.
Positions of A, B, and C relative to D and E might influence flow direction.
Baffles might channel liquid from all points A, B, and C to one container.
Considering interaction between flows from A, B, and C, whether they merge or remain separate.
General approach for fluid flow problems with baffles involves tracing liquid path based on configuration.
Thinking of the setup as a simple drainage system with baffles directing water flow to outlets D and E.
Position and orientation of baffles determine which outlet the water from each point flows into.
If a baffle directs flow from A to D and from B and C to E, then liquid from A goes to D, and from B and C to E.
If baffles are set up to direct all flow to D, then all liquid from A, B, and C goes to D.
